landing.title: Match your vote to South Africa

howItHelps.title: Why this matters now
howItHelps.intro: Coalitions, load-shedding, jobs, safety, housing. Compare parties on the issues that shape daily life in South Africa.

benefit1.title: Look past slogans
benefit1.text: See actual positions on service delivery, energy, crime, jobs, and land — not just campaign posters.

benefit2.title: Spot real options
benefit2.text: Find parties you may not follow, based on policy fit instead of social media reach.

benefit3.title: Read the field
benefit3.text: Get a ranked view of every party so you can see where they bunch together and where they split.

benefit4.title: Walk into the booth ready
benefit4.text: Decide with clarity before you queue. Save or share a link to your own answers.

about.title: About Elekti
about.methodologyText: Elekti is rooted in South African policy documents and public statements. We score across 12 issue areas that affect daily life and governance. The maths is deterministic and transparent.
about.howItWorksText: Fifty questions cover power, water, housing, jobs, safety, transport, coalitions, social policy, and accountability. Each question links to an issue axis. You answer, we map your stance, and we compare it to each party's stated position.
about.scoringText: For every axis we calculate similarity between your answers and each party, weight by question importance, normalise by the questions you answered, then average across all axes. Scores are percentages; confidence reflects how clear the gap is between your top match and the rest.
about.transparencyText: All positions, weights, and calculations live in the repo. If something is wrong, send sources and we'll update. This tool is independent and does not promote any party.
about.dataSourcesText: We rely on manifestos, policy documents, voting records, budget speeches, and verified public statements. When positions change, we update.
about.privacyText: Your answers never leave your device. No accounts, no identifiers.
about.noTrackingText: We don't use cookies or pixels that follow you. We cannot see who you are or what you answered.
about.localOnlyText: Everything is saved in your browser. Clear your data and it's gone; we have nothing on our side.
about.sharingText: Sharing creates a URL that encodes your answers. Anyone with the link can view your result. Remove the link to keep it private again.
about.analyticsText: We use privacy-first, cookie-free analytics only to see if people are visiting. They do not record your answers.
about.partiesText: We list major parties contesting nationally and in key provinces this cycle. If we missed one, point us to their published policies.
about.disclaimerText: Use this as a starting point. Read manifestos, attend community meetings, and test our data. Politics shifts; so should your judgement.
about.viewDataText: All JSON files for questions, weights, and party positions are public. Inspect them yourself.

anc.desc: The African National Congress is South Africa's governing party, advocating for social democracy, transformation, and addressing inequality through state intervention.

da.desc: The Democratic Alliance promotes liberal democracy, free market economics, and non-racial politics with emphasis on good governance and job creation.

mk.desc: uMkhonto we Sizwe Party focuses on radical economic transformation, advocating for state-led development and addressing historical injustices.

eff.desc: The Economic Freedom Fighters is a far-left party advocating for radical economic transformation, nationalization, and land redistribution without compensation.

ifp.desc: The Inkatha Freedom Party primarily represents Zulu communities, promoting Zulu cultural values, federalism, and free market economics with social responsibility. While it has broader appeal, policy priorities centre on Zulu traditions and KwaZulu-Natal interests.

pa.desc: The Patriotic Alliance focuses on addressing immigration issues, promoting South African nationalism, and prioritising citizens' needs.

vfplus.name: Freedom Front Plus
vfplus.desc: Freedom Front Plus primarily represents Afrikaner communities and interests, advocating for federalism, minority rights, and conservative values. Policy priorities centre on Afrikaner cultural preservation and self-determination.

actionsa.desc: ActionSA is a centrist party focused on practical governance, anti-corruption, and economic growth through private sector engagement.

acdp.desc: The African Christian Democratic Party promotes Christian values, conservative social policies, and constitutional democracy.

ufc.desc: Unite for Change focuses on grassroots mobilisation and addressing local community concerns through progressive policies.

udm.desc: The United Democratic Movement is a social democratic party emphasising good governance, anti-corruption, and balanced economic policies with merit-based appointments.

sacp.desc: The South African Communist Party advocates for socialism, workers' rights and a transition to a socialist society through state control.

atm.desc: The African Transformation Movement is a Christian democratic party advocating for conservative values, the death penalty, and stricter educational standards.

aljama-ah.desc: Al Jama-ah is an Islamic democratic party promoting Muslim interests, social democracy, and conservative social values while working for all South Africans.

ncc.desc: The National Coloured Congress represents Coloured community interests and advocates for addressing issues affecting the Coloured population.

pac.desc: The Pan Africanist Congress of Azania is a Black nationalist party advocating for African socialism, Pan-Africanism, and land reform based on African ownership.

q1.text: The government should raise taxes on the wealthy to fund expanded social programmes (health, education, social grants).

q2.text: Fiscal discipline and reducing public debt should be prioritised even if it limits new social spending.

q3.text: The state should introduce a universal basic income for all citizens.

q4.text: The state should use public works programmes to reduce unemployment.

q5.text: Healthcare should be universally publicly funded, with basic services free at point of use.

q6.text: Higher education should be free for all students, even if it requires higher taxes.

q7.text: The state should provide strong subsidies for childcare to support working parents.

q8.text: Industrial policy should include protective measures and subsidies for emerging black-owned and worker-owned enterprises.

q9.text: The government should actively support small and medium businesses with tax breaks and deregulation.

q10.text: Key public utilities (power, water, rail) should remain publicly owned and not be privatised.

q11.text: Private companies should be allowed to generate and sell electricity to end load-shedding, even if this reduces Eskom's role.

q12.text: Water supply and sanitation services should remain primarily state-controlled rather than be opened to private operators.

q13.text: Expropriation of land without market-rate compensation should be allowed to speed up land reform.

q14.text: Smallholder farming and communal land rights should receive priority policy support over large commercial agribusiness.

q15.text: Community-owned agricultural initiatives and cooperative farming models should be actively supported by government policy and funding.

q16.text: Traditional and indigenous land rights should be legally recognised and protected, even if this conflicts with existing property titles.

q17.text: Workers should have stronger rights to unionise and strike, with fewer restrictions.

q18.text: Minimum wages should be increased significantly to reduce in-work poverty, even if some small businesses struggle.

q19.text: Labour market flexibility (easier hiring and firing) will increase investment and should be encouraged.

q20.text: Workplace rights such as paid leave, sick leave, and severance pay should be strengthened and actively enforced across all sectors.

q21.text: Police should be given stronger powers and resources to tackle violent crime, even if it expands state authority.

q22.text: Freedom of expression and peaceful protest should be prioritised even when demonstrations disrupt economic activity.

q23.text: South Africa should adopt strong digital privacy laws limiting corporate and state surveillance.

q24.text: Disruptive protests and shutdowns should face stronger legal limits, even if this restricts certain forms of political expression.

q25.text: Local government should be professionally staffed and independently audited to address municipal failures and corruption, even if this limits political appointments.

q26.text: Independent oversight institutions (judiciary, prosecution) should be protected even if it slows prosecutions of powerful officials.

q27.text: Corruption prosecutions should be fast and aggressive even if they cause short-term instability in government.

q28.text: Political parties should compromise on their ideological positions to form stable coalition governments, even if this disappoints some supporters.

q29.text: National government should intervene more aggressively in failing municipalities, even if this limits local democratic autonomy.

q30.text: Political leaders who publicly undermine the judiciary, electoral bodies, or the Constitution should face consequences.

q31.text: South Africa should set legally binding targets to cut greenhouse gas emissions and phase out coal power.

q32.text: The state should prioritise investment in renewable energy to reduce dependence on coal power.

q33.text: Environmental protection laws should take priority over new mineral and coal developments.

q34.text: The state should enforce LGBTQ+ anti-discrimination protections and inclusion policies.

q35.text: The state should actively promote gender equality through mandatory parental leave policies and workplace anti-discrimination enforcement.

q36.text: South Africa should prioritise export-led growth through stronger trade links with international markets.

q37.text: South Africa should actively pursue free trade agreements and reduce trade barriers to integrate more deeply into the global economy.

q38.text: Trade policy should prioritise protecting local industries through tariffs and local content rules.

q39.text: South Africa should adopt stricter immigration and border enforcement policies, even if this strains relations with neighbouring countries.

q40.text: Government should more aggressively regulate the employment of undocumented foreign nationals, even if this disrupts industries that rely on migrant labour.

q41.text: Food security should be achieved through a national strategy supporting local production, agroecology and community gardens.

q42.text: South Africa should prioritise radical restructuring of the economy and labour market over gradual, market-driven reforms.

q43.text: The apartheid-era legacy should be addressed through incremental institutional reforms rather than sweeping systemic overhauls.

q44.text: Transport infrastructure funding should prioritise mass public transit over new highway construction, even if this inconveniences motorists.

q45.text: Affordable public housing projects should be prioritised over incentives for private housing developers.

q46.text: Cities should be legally required to restrict low-density, car-dependent developments and mandate walkable, mixed-use neighbourhoodsâ€”even if this limits property rights.

q47.text: Government departments must meet strict accessibility standards for people with disabilities, even if this impacts other services.

q48.text: The state should introduce targeted subsidies and incentives to accelerate township and rural economies.

q49.text: Policies such as Employment Equity and BEE should remain central tools for addressing racial inequality, even if they limit flexibility for businesses.

q50.text: Skills development programmes should be targeted at historically disadvantaged individuals to accelerate economic participation.

disclaimer.title: Use this as a guide
disclaimer.educational: Elekti helps you compare parties. It does not replace your own research, and positions can shift as coalitions and policy debates move.
disclaimer.alpha: This site is under active development. We update data as parties publish and adjust their stances.
disclaimer.research: Read manifestos, budget speeches, council plans, and community briefings. If you spot issues in our data, send sources and we will correct them.
